archetype.archetype_expression: The passionate scholar who has dedicated their life to collecting and sharing the world's mythological traditions. Academic rigor with accessible presentation. Treats ancient stories with the respect they deserve while making them engaging for modern readers. Indiana Jones meets your favorite professor.

soul.one_sentence: A scholar's study where the world's mythological traditions come alive through meticulous curation and genuine wonder.
soul.expanded: We are the keepers of humanity's oldest stories. Every culture has myths that explain their world—creation stories, hero journeys, explanations of natural phenomena. We collect, contextualize, and share these traditions with academic accuracy and genuine enthusiasm. This is not entertainment; this is preservation of human heritage.
soul.what_we_are: A serious but accessible resource for mythology. A bridge between academic scholarship and public curiosity. A place that treats all cultural traditions with equal respect and rigor.
soul.what_we_are_not: Not pop culture interpretations (Marvel, Disney). Not appropriation without context. Not ranking myths as 'better' or 'worse'. Not treating living traditions as museum pieces.

if_this_site_were.person: A 55-year-old professor of comparative mythology with wild gray hair and kind eyes. They've traveled to study traditions firsthand, speak multiple languages, and light up when discussing any culture's stories. Their office is filled with artifacts, books in various languages, and hand-drawn maps. They treat a student's question about Percy Jackson with the same respect as a doctoral thesis inquiry.
if_this_site_were.place: A vast private library in an old university building. Dark wood shelves reaching to high ceilings. Leather-bound volumes in dozens of languages. A large globe that shows ancient trade routes. Artifacts in glass cases from cultures around the world. Soft light from green banker's lamps. The smell of old paper and possibility.
if_this_site_were.time_of_day: Late afternoon in autumn when golden light streams through tall windows, dust motes floating in the air, the quiet of concentrated study.
if_this_site_were.season: Autumn—the time of harvests, reflection, when the veil between worlds grows thin in Celtic tradition, appropriate for studying the old ways.
if_this_site_were.sound: Pages turning. Distant clock ticking. Perhaps rain against leaded windows. Occasionally, the scratch of pen on paper. Profound, comfortable silence.
if_this_site_were.texture: Aged leather book bindings. Smooth vellum. Rough stone artifacts. The weight of a heavy tome in your hands.
if_this_site_were.smell: Old books. Leather. Wood polish. Perhaps incense from far-off lands. Coffee from the professor's cup.
if_this_site_were.taste: Strong coffee. Perhaps tea with honey. The imagined taste of ancient feasts described in texts.
if_this_site_were.temperature: Warm despite the old building. Comfortable enough to spend hours reading.
if_this_site_were.weather: Misty, atmospheric. The kind of day that makes you want to stay inside with books.
if_this_site_were.music_genre: Classical, particularly pieces inspired by mythology—Holst's Planets, Wagner (problematically), Rimsky-Korsakov. World traditional music from cultures being studied.
if_this_site_were.movie: The Mummy (1999) meets Dead Poets Society—adventure and scholarship together.
if_this_site_were.book: A comprehensive encyclopedia with beautiful illustrations, primary source translations, and comprehensive citations.

primary_persona.name: Curious Casey
primary_persona.description: Someone fascinated by mythology who wants to go deeper than Wikipedia or pop culture interpretations. Could be a student, writer, game developer, or simply a mythology enthusiast. Values accuracy but doesn't have academic access.
primary_persona.mindset: Genuinely curious, wants real information, tired of surface-level content. May have been inspired by games, books, or movies but wants authentic sources.
goals: Understand myths in their original cultural context
Find accurate information for creative projects
Access scholarly knowledge without academic paywalls
pain_points: Pop culture has distorted the stories
Hard to know what's authentic vs. modern invention
Don't know where to start with unfamiliar traditions
objections: Are you qualified to discuss these cultures?
Is this just another pop culture wiki?

secondary_persona.name: Creative Colin
secondary_persona.description: A writer, game developer, or artist looking for mythological inspiration with authentic details. Needs accurate information to create respectful interpretations.
secondary_persona.how_they_differ: Specifically seeking usable creative material, needs details about appearance, symbols, stories

tertiary_persona.name: Student Sam
tertiary_persona.description: A student researching for a paper or project. Needs citable, reliable information with proper sources.
tertiary_persona.how_they_differ: Needs academic rigor, citations, primary source references

anti_persona.description: Someone looking for 'proof' that one culture's mythology is 'right' or 'better'. Someone wanting to appropriate sacred traditions. Someone only interested in pop culture versions.
anti_persona.why_not: We don't rank cultures. We don't enable appropriation. We provide context, not just entertainment.

visual_philosophy.overall_aesthetic: Scholarly warmth—the feeling of entering a well-loved library

density.description: Content-rich but organized. Like a well-designed encyclopedia.
density.section_breathing: Clear sections, generous margins, readable columns
density.never: Never overwhelming. Never cluttered. Never wall-of-text without breaks.

contrast.description: Warm contrast. Cream/sepia tones with dark text. Like aged paper.
contrast.approach: High readability with comfortable warmth. Not harsh white, not too dark.
contrast.never: Never stark modern contrast. Never cold clinical white.

motion.description: Subtle, elegant, restrained. Like pages turning.
motion.style: Fade and gentle reveals. Nothing bouncy or playful.
motion.never: Never flashy. Never attention-grabbing. Never gaming-style.

texture.description: Subtle paper and parchment feels. Old book quality.
texture.never: Never grungy. Never damaged. Never obstructing readability.

shape_language.border_radius_philosophy: Minimal—2-4px at most. Classical, not bubbly.
shape_language.line_weight: Thin, elegant lines. Reminiscent of manuscript decoration.
shape_language.never: Never fully rounded. Never sharp brutal corners. Never modern minimalist.

depth.shadow_style: Very soft, suggesting depth of stacked pages
depth.never: Never material design depth. Never floating cards.

required_flow: Welcoming scholarly introduction—what this archive contains
forbidden_flow: Pop culture references front and center

hero_requirements.content_placement: Clear introduction, paths to major sections
hero_requirements.cta_style: Explore by Culture, Search the Archives, New to Mythology?

single_posts.layout_type: Single column, article format, generous margins
single_posts.sidebar_usage: Contextual: Related entries, culture overview, key facts
single_posts.related_content_style: Related myths, same culture, connected deities

grid_philosophy.grid_breaking: Featured or important entries can span wider

responsive_philosophy.mobile_approach: Maintain readability above all. Single column, comfortable text.
responsive_philosophy.tablet_approach: Two columns where appropriate, maintain scholarly feel

navigation.philosophy: Directory + Discovery—organized index with exploration encouraged

search.style: Full search with filters by culture, type, etc.

headings.personality: Classical, scholarly, elegant. The font of serious books.

body.personality: Highly readable serif, comfortable for long reading sessions

accent.usage: Pull quotes, chapter headers, special designations

accent.name: Dark Goldenrod
accent.max_usage: Less than 5%—like gold leaf, precious and rare

illustration_style.approach: Historical art reproduction or scholarly diagrams

iconography.style: Cultural symbols drawn accurately, properly attributed

must_include.description: Clear visual indicator of which tradition an entry belongs to
Origin and meaning of names in original language

usage_rules.restraint_philosophy: Scholarly restraint—decoration is secondary to information

custom_ui_elements.cards: Like catalog entries, clean and informative
custom_ui_elements.dividers: Cultural patterns or simple elegant lines

tone_spectrum.serious_playful: 8/10 - Treats subject seriously with genuine enthusiasm

writing_style.sentence_length: Varied—clear explanations, some longer for nuance

voice.perspective: Third person scholarly, occasional second person for engagement
encouraged_phrases: This reflects the culture's view of

what_perfect_looks_like: Would be cited in a research paper
Treats every culture with equal scholarly respect
Visual design matches scholarly quality of content
A comparative mythology professor would approve

tests.screenshot_test: Would a mythology professor use this with students?
tests.swap_test: Could this be mistaken for a gaming wiki? (Must fail)
tests.memory_test: Did the reader learn something substantive?
tests.ten_second_test: Is it immediately clear this is serious scholarship?

competitive_positioning.how_we_differ: More accessible than Theoi, more rigorous than Wikipedia, broader than niche sites
competitive_positioning.what_they_do_wrong: Either too academic or too shallow, often single-culture focused
competitive_positioning.what_we_do_better: Balance of accessibility and rigor, global scope, beautiful presentation

seo.internal_linking_strategy: Extensive cross-linking between related entries. Culture hubs link to all entries. Entries link to related deities, creatures, stories.
seo.content_depth_target: Major deities: 3000+, Secondary figures: 1500+, Creatures: 1000+, Quick references: 500+
